subject: Michael the Eagle
event:
And yes, Virginia, there are other things going on in the world besides the HBO pilot.

Like the NFL.

So the Eagles have signed Michael Vick.  OK.  I'm glad it was not the Giants or the Jets, truthfully... though I do believe in second chances, and Vick has served his time.  Even so, I wouldn't want him on my team.  If his skills have not eroded too badly in prison, he will be a dangerous weapon for the Eagles, and my Giants have to face them twice... and sometimes three times... a year.  So this clearly makes the Birds the favorites in the NFC East.

Fine with me.  The G-Men always do better as underdogs.

comments.article: Michael Vick should play Hodor!

At long last an update on the NFL, I was beginning to wonder if you would ever post on the subject again.
Have a great season. By the way, are any of the NFL players used as the basis for the Mountain?
comments.subject: NFL

comments.article: I was hoping Vick would get signed by the Browns, so he could get in trouble for Dawg-fighting.
Given Mr Vick's prior record, is 'underdog' perhaps not the most suitable word in this context...? ;)

My problem with Vick is that some crimes require a certain moral void, Like forcing man's best friend into a death match. The fact that he is capable of such malice says a lot about his character, IMO second chances are for things like theft or selling pot, not coldly murdering numerous innocent creatures to entertain yourself.

some crimes require a certain moral void

I'll agree, and go a couple of steps further. (and a step backward in selling pot, which I don't have any issues w/at all)

Let's look at types of moral void in different crimes --

Drive by shooting of someone you don't know or who you do know is innocent of any serious wrong-doing-- Somehow, you didn't think about what the impact of what you were doing on someone else, or didn't care. Moral void of a sort, here. But, you still don't actually have to *see* the consequences of what you did, so there's some possibility even tho you don't get it, you can get it and one day might.

Torturing someone (and assuming that person didn't just kill your best friend or something), or killing them slowly up close and personal -- Much huger moral void; you are right there sitting through the consequences and continuing to do them. Vick was doing this when he put the dogs through the fights, and when he beat them, sometimes to death, for not fighting the way he wanted. Or when he watched his friends do this.

Torturing and killing over and over and over again -- This is Vick. He was there, he saw what the consequences of his actions were; he had time to think or feel. It made no impact on him at all. He had a whole bunch of second and even 100th chances to see and feel and think about the torture he was inflicting on innocents, and he still kept getting off on him. To use an asoiaf reference, he deserves another chance about as much as Gregor Clegane or the Bloody Mummers.

I was pulling for the Eagles to win the super bowl, because I'd like to see Donovan McNabb get one. Now, I hope they lose every game. What else I hope I shall not say, cause y'all will probably think that involves a moral void on my part. Let's just say I believe in vengeance and wish I believed in karma. Karma, please show up. =)

I know someone was bound to pick him up, but I'm still surprised anyone picked him up, I'd think grabbing him would piss off the fans, better those birds than mine...


Go Seahawks

always my favourite post every year from my favourite football pundit, writing about my two favorite teams!
lets hope the fresh G-men can catch and the wet behind the ears QB can continue the successful trend of rookie QBs in the NFL for Gang Green!

Looking forward to your takes on Pre-season!
comments.subject: ARE YOU READY FOR SOME FOOTBAALLL!

comments.article: I don't think anything good is going to come of it, personally. Which is just as well, as I'm no Eagles fan.
I don't think anything good is going to come of it, personally. Which is depressing, as I'm an Eagles fan.

As a lifelong Eagles fan, I couldn't be more shocked or angered by the signing of Vick.  This guy is not sorry about what he did, he is only sorry about getting caught.  Don't forget that its not just Pit Bulls that were getting beaten, electrocuted, and hung by this guy and his organization, it was also HUNDREDS of "Bait Dogs".  These are dogs that they would go and get from shelters and pounds or stolen out of peoples back yards that are used to let the fighting dogs practice killing.  Well, what else can be expected from Andy Reid, that wonderful judge of character, look at the two outstanding young men he managed to raise. Go G-men, F the Eagles.
comments.subject: Disappointed Eagles Fan

comments.article: I wonder if he asks for discounts at record stores NOW.

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: facepalm
comments.article: hahaha.
I think this will be a mistake for the Eagles. I've heard PETA is going to be having a nice big protest at Eagles training camp today. Vick is going to be a huge distraction.

As much as I don't like Michael Vick, my Philadelphean blood runs strong. I had to really try to resist the temptation to reply with, "Flyyyyyy Eagles, flyyyyy, on the road to victory!"

That said, there are some positive developments in Philly that came with Vick's signing: Protesters were seen outside the stadium carrying signs. The most memorable one said: "Watch your beagle! Vick's an Eagle!" They showed it on the local news, and it made me laugh.
As a Philthadelphian, I am less than happy. I don't even LIKE football (sorry, George!)... but I am not best pleased at the thought of an animal murderer being associated with my city. Blech.
Some people don't deserve a second chance!
comments.subject: Thumbs down Eagles

comments.article:
Sorry George, but "his time" was what, like three months or something? The chances are very, very good that anyone not-Michael Vick would have had to serve a lot more time in prison over something like what he did...

I think the Eagles made a gigantic PR mistake here. Even if he has cleaned up his act, the masses are asses as they say. They won't be so forgiving.

comments.upictitle: Some guy in a maze: animated black mage
comments.article: The Eagles ARE a gigantic PR mistake usually. So I suppose this is in keeping. Now I gotta figure out if I can actually cheer for them at all this year. Probably not. Damned conscience.

if he does I disagree what concern a professional player in a movie so, best a real actor a despite he will not act a lot.
The difference will be perceptible.
comments.subject: a NFL player?

comments.article:
From what I heard, McNabb was the one who was pressing for him. I never thought Vick was that great. He was ok as a QB, and he could run well, but was not good enough to be a RB. Eh, i think the eagles will go 10-6.

Btw, I heard that Eli signed a 6 year, 96 million contract. Wow. Not bad for a QB that is only good, but not great. (Of course, I am still smarting from the super bowl two years ago, where I woke up the next morning going "how the f#^@ did my patriots lose to the GIANTS?!?", so I am not bitter or anything. ;)

comments.upictitle: The Kwisatz Haderach, Give A Dog A Bone: pic#80183639
comments.article: Wow, the term "underdog" has unfortunate implications when used in a conversation about Michael Vick.
I hope one of the Giants injures him so badly he'll never play again.
comments.subject: As a pitbull owner

comments.article:
::applause::

Though your hope/imagination is slightly nicer/less vindictive than mine.
comments.subject: Re: As a pitbull owner

comments.article: I agree everyone deserves a second chance, and given Michael Vick is no exception.  I must admit to being equally relieved that he's not going to a team I care deeply about, however. Having him at my Cowboys (unlikely) or over at the Bucs (and who knows what they're thinking lately) could've really soured things for me.  So, rejoice!  Now we are free to talk about the importance of second chances, in the comfortable abstract! :P

"And yes, Virginia, there are other things going on in the world besides the HBO pilot."
No. there ARE no other things going on in the world besides the HBO pilot...
comments.subject: No. George

comments.article: As an Eagles fan I think it was a good decision.  Placing him under McNabb will hopefully have a positive influence.  Mcnabb already spoke about how he wants Vick to observe his routine and discipline.  At least he's being given a real second chance, instead of going to a team that will pump his head up, treat him like a savior, then toss him aside if he doesnt adjust.  McNabb seems to really want the challenge of turning him into a model player and teammate. If he messes up this one it will be on him.

Unless Vick's magically gotten slow and old, he should be a good weapon to have lining up as a receiver, RB, or wildcat back. I think just having him on the field will make teams think twice, and should allow McNabb to really cement himself as QB, despite what his fears may whisper.

I think Vick deserves a second chance after servinghis time and would've liked him on the Bucs, but that's not really how they're trying to rebuild their team. Philly seems an odd choice, but as he alluded to, Andy Reid has seen second chances in his own life.
comments.subject: Definitely takes pressure off of Westbrook

comments.article:
If the Giants and Jets fought in a jousting tournament, who would win?

You may be the one man on earth most qualified to answer that question, George.
